values:
The purpose of this journal is to write 99 reviews on the 99 books that I will be reading this year.  Just a new goal that I came up with five seconds ago.  Not a new years resolution but something to give purpose to my journal and hopefully keep you interested.  It'll be strictly book reviews and personal entries are for friends only!

So, just introduce yourself and I'll add you :)

Title: Foundling Series: Monster Blood Tattoo Auther: D.M Cornish Genre: Fantasy, Young Adult Fiction Pages: 433 (including appendix and glossary) Rating: 5/5 from the blurb

The vast lands of the Half-Continent bear the scars of centuries of conflict between humans and monsters. Only the hardiest souls now travel the inland ways: merchants, Imperial messengers and - bravest of all - the monster-hunters. To be a hunter takes great cunning and extraordinary skill, for the creatures are as deadly as they are varied. Bogles, rever-men, grinnlings and nickers - any one can kill a human quicker than thought. Not that Rossamund Bookchild should worry. The orphan boy with the girl's name lives safe within the walls of the Madam Opera's Estimable Marine Society for Foundling Boys and Girls. Safe, at least, until the da he is recruited into the service of the Empire by a strange man with blood-red yes. This is his story. Foundling is the first of a three book series called Monster Blood Tattoo. It is about a “foundling” boy burdened with a girl’s name, Rossamund (but he’s no longer bothered by it). At the beginning of the book he is living in an orphanage fighting against the daily bullies in his life but is often looked after by his kind mentors, who are very protective of him. Rossamund dreams to be a vinegaroon (sailor). When the time comes to be chosen for a career Rossamund’s life takes a more interesting and dangerous turn in which he’ll be confronted with monsters and dangerous humans. The Monster Blood Tattoo series is unlike any fantasy series I have read before. D.M Cornish has so detailingly created his half-continent it is hard to believe it imaginary. What surprises me most is that D.M Cornish has created a word or phrase for every element “fantastic” or otherwise. The use of neologisms in this series is incredible and proof of the amount of thought that D.M Cornish has put into his books (the second is out now). Everything has a name or phrase to describe the people, places and objects in the story. Things such as potives, biggins, sethnicons, and people who are leers, fulgars and lamplighters. All are explored in great detail in the glossary and with examples from the glossary highlighted at the beginning of each chapter so the reader can follow any new word introduced as they read along. However, the neologisms were good but at times frustrating. I was often confused and, although I was enjoying each new word; I found it difficult to remember. Each time I came across one of these fantastic new words I would quickly forget it because another would quickly follow suit. The glossary was there, yes, but I would get irritated by the idea of flicking to the end of the book to discover what it meant. Overall; I thoroughly enjoyed the book. It was exciting, and even though at times too detailed, the adventures of Rossamund and Europe were fantastic and gripping. After reading the second book now I have found myself enjoying the language of D.M Cornish.

Title: Coraline Auther: Neil Gaiman Genre: Fantasy, Horror Pages: 162 Rating: 5/5 from the blurb When Coraline steps through a door to find another house strangely similar to her own (only better), things seem marvelous. But there's another mother there, and another father, and they want her to stay and be their little girl. They want to change her and never let her go. Coraline will have to fight with all her wits and courage if she is to save herself and return to her ordinary life. Coraline is definitely one of my favourite reads of 2009. It has that classic Alice in Wonderland falling into the rabbit hole element, in other words, crossing the threshold into another world. I have always loved when writers play with the idea that curiosity leads to a wonderful adventure, when the hero follows their instincts and regretfully finds themselves in danger that not only challenges them but changes them forever. Gaiman’s imagination certainly follows that classic element of fantasy novels that can only be on par with Lewis Carroll. He’s quite inventive in how he portrays Coraline, a young stubborn girl who is brave and smart and takes her along a journey that certainly forces Coraline to use these traits to the best of her advantage. The “other” mother is certainly frightful and even though it’s supposed to be a young adult novel, she still gave me the shivers and is certainly the epitome of a nightmare. The other characters are just as interesting and colourful as Coraline, as the story is written through Coraline’s point of view she seems to be a little more elaborate in her description of the people she meets. As any child with a huge imagination does. I really enjoyed this novel and think it is a great read for young readers, especially for those who might be a little resistant. The book is clear and an easy read, as it is through the eyes of a young girl (early teens) though certainly intriguing and charming. If you have seen the movie, it is just as good if not better than the film.
